entry.title: Charles Holland (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that opera singer Charles Holland (pictured) spent much of his career in Europe as opportunities in classical music for African Americans were limited?

entry.title: Thorpe (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that Thorpe's secluded hills provided refuge from Scottish raiders and English Civil War troops?

entry.title: Predator: The Secret Scandal of J-Pop (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that until the release of the documentary Predator: The Secret Scandal of J-Pop, sexual abuse claims involving record producer Johnny Kitagawa went widely unreported in Japanese media?

entry.title: Okanagrion (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that the damselfly relative Okanagrion is suggested to have eight species due to both alpha and beta diversity drivers?

entry.title: Thoriqul Haq (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that even though a village said that it did not want a church, Indonesian politician Thoriqul Haq allocated land and money to build one along with a musalla?

entry.title: Eurovision Song Contest 1990 (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that the Eurovision Song Contest 1990, held in Yugoslavia, was the first Eurovision Song Contest to be held in the Balkans or in a socialist state?

entry.title: Amanda Jones (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that librarian Amanda Jones won an award from the American Library Association for not backing down after receiving death threats for speaking out against book censorship?

entry.title: committee of Chinese compatriots of all circles from Hong Kong Island and Kowloon struggled against what they viewed as persecution by the British authorities in Hong Kong (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that a committee of Chinese compatriots of all circles from Hong Kong Island and Kowloon struggled against what they viewed as persecution by the British authorities in Hong Kong?
